column1: AAA:2FA: Two-factor Authentication: An authentication method requiring two distinct forms of identification to verify a user's identity.
AAA:AAA: Authentication
column3: and Accounting: A framework for controlling access to computer resources
column6: and providing information necessary to bill for services.

column1: AAA:ACL: Access Control List: A list of permissions associated with an object
column2: specifying which users or system processes are granted access to objects
column3: as well as what operations are allowed on given objects.

column1: AAA:CAPTCHA: Completely Automated Public Turing Test to Tell Computers and Humans Apart: A type of challenge-response test used in computing to determine whether or not the user is human.
AAA:DAC: Discretionary Access Control: An access control model where the owner of a resource can decide who can access it and what permissions they have.
AAA:DKIM: DomainKeys Identified Mail: An email authentication method designed to detect forged sender addresses in emails.

AAA:DMARC: Domain Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance: An email authentication protocol that builds on SPF and DKIM to give email senders the ability to protect their domain from unauthorized use.
AAA:EAP: Extensible Authentication Protocol: An authentication framework that supports multiple authentication methods.
AAA:EFS: Encrypted File System: A feature of Windows that allows for files and folders to be encrypted individually.
AAA:FACL: File System Access Control List: A list of permissions associated with an object
column2: specifying which users or system processes are granted access to objects
column3: as well as what operations are allowed on given objects at the file system level.

column1: AAA:FIM: File Integrity Management: A process that involves validating the integrity of operating system and application software files using a verification method.
AAA:FRR: False Rejection Rate: The rate at which legitimate users are denied access by an authentication system.
AAA:IAM: Identity and Access Management: A framework of policies and technologies to ensure that the right people have the appropriate access to technology resources.
AAA:MAC: Mandatory Access Control: An access control model where the operating system or security kernel enforces access control policy.
AAA:MAC: Message Authentication Code: A short piece of information used to authenticate a message and provide integrity and authenticity.
AAA:MFA: Multifactor Authentication: An authentication method requiring two or more distinct forms of identification to verify a user's identity.
AAA:OAUTH: Open Authorization: An open standard for access delegation
column2: commonly used as a way for Internet users to grant websites or applications access to their information on other websites without giving them their passwords.

column1: AAA:OID: Object Identifier: A hierarchical name used to uniquely identify an object or object class.
AAA:PAM: Privileged Access Management: Solutions that help organizations manage and secure privileged accounts.
AAA:PAM: Pluggable Authentication Modules: A mechanism for integrating low-level authentication schemes into a higher-level API.
AAA:RADIUS: Remote Authentication Dial-in User Service: A networking protocol that provides centralized Authentication
column3: and Accounting (AAA) management for users connecting and using a network service.

column1: AAA:RBAC: Role-based Access Control: An access control model where access is granted based on the user's role within an organization.
AAA:RBAC: Rule-based Access Control: An access control model where access is granted based on a set of predefined rules.
AAA:RFID: Radio Frequency Identifier: The use of radio waves to identify objects or people automatically.
AAA:SAE: Simultaneous Authentication of Equals: An authentication method used in Wi-Fi Protected Access 3 (WPA3).
AAA:SPF: Sender Policy Framework: An email authentication method designed to detect forged sender addresses in emails.
AAA:SSO: Single Sign-on: An authentication scheme that allows a user to log in with a single ID and password to gain access to multiple related but independent software systems.
AAA:TGT: Ticket Granting Ticket: A special type of Kerberos ticket that allows a client to obtain additional service tickets without re-authenticating.
Applications:API: Application Programming Interface: A set of defined rules that enable different applications to communicate with each other.
Applications:DLL: Dynamic Link Library: A library that contains code and data that can be used by more than one program at the same time.
Applications:PUP: Potentially Unwanted Program: A program that may be unwanted by the user
Applications:RAD: Rapid Application Development: A software development methodology that prioritizes rapid prototyping and quick delivery.
Applications:SDK: Software Development Kit: A collection of software development tools in one installable package.
Applications:SDLC: Software Development Lifecycle: A conceptual model used in project management that describes the stages involved in an information system development project.
Applications:SDLM: Software Development Lifecycle Methodology: A framework that details the steps involved in developing software.
Applications:SEH: Structured Exception Handler: Microsoft-specific mechanism designed to handle and provide low-level control over errors/faults/exception.
Applications:SQL: Structured Query Language: A domain-specific language used in programming and designed for managing data held in a relational database management system
column2: or for stream processing in a relational data stream management system.

column1: Applications:UAT: User Acceptance Testing: The final stage of any software development process where the actual software users test the software to ensure it can handle the required tasks in real-world scenarios.
Applications:VBA: Visual Basic: An event-driven programming language and associated integrated development environment (IDE) from Microsoft.
Applications:VDE: Virtual Desktop Environment: A desktop environment that is accessed remotely from a client device.
Applications:HTML: Hypertext Markup Language: The standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser.
Applications:XML: Extensible Markup Language: A markup language that defines a set of rules for encoding documents in a format that is both human-readable and machine-readable.
Applications:SD-WAN: Software-defined Wide Area Network: A modern approach to managing and optimizing wide area networks using software-based technologies (for creating smart WANs).
Applications:SDN: Software-defined Networking: A modern approach to managing computer networks that emphasizes flexibility
Applications:VDI: Virtual Desktop Infrastructure: A desktop virtualization technology that hosts desktop operating systems and applications on a centralized server.
Attacks:CSRF: Cross-site Request Forgery: An attack that forces an end user to execute unwanted actions on a web application in which they're currently authenticated.
Attacks:SPIM: Spam over Internet Messaging: Unsolicited commercial or malicious messages sent over instant messaging.
Attacks:SQLi: SQL Injection: A code injection technique used to attack data-driven applications
column2: in which malicious SQL statements are inserted into an entry field for execution.

column1: Attacks:XSRF: Cross-site Request Forgery: An attack that forces an end user to execute unwanted actions on a web application in which they're currently authenticated. (Same as CSRF)
Attacks:XSS: Cross-site Scripting: A type of security vulnerability typically found in web applications that enables attackers to inject client-side scripts into web pages viewed by other users.
Business:ALE: Annualized Loss Expectancy: The expected monetary loss for an asset or a group of assets over a one-year period.
Business:ARO: Annualized Rate of Occurrence: The likelihood
column3: that a specific threat or risk will occur within a single year.

column1: Business:AUP: Acceptable Use Policy: A document outlining the rules and practices that individuals must follow to use a computer network or other resources.
Business:BCP: Business Continuity Planning: The process of creating systems of prevention and recovery to deal with potential threats to a company.
Business:BIA: Business Impact Analysis: A systematic process to determine and evaluate the potential effects of an interruption to critical business operations as a result of a disaster
Business:BPA: Business Partners Agreement: A legal document defining responsibilities
column3: and liabilities between two or more business partners.

column1: Business:CERT: Computer Emergency Response Team: An expert group that handles computer security incidents.
Business:CIO: Chief Information Officer: An executive who oversees the use of information technology and computer systems.
Business:CIRT: Computer Incident Response Team: A team responsible for reacting to computer security incidents and breaches.
Business:COBO: Corporate-owned
column2: Business-only: A mobile device deployment model where devices are owned by the company and used strictly for business purposes.

column1: Business:COOP: Continuity of Operation Planning: A government initiative to ensure that essential functions can be continued in the event of a catastrophic emergency.
Business:COPE: Corporate Owned
column2: Personally Enabled: A mobile device deployment model where devices are owned by the company but employees are allowed to use them for personal activities.

column1: Business:CP: Contingency Planning: The process of preparing for unforeseen events or disasters that could disrupt business operations.
Business:CSO: Chief Security Officer: An executive responsible for the security of an organization's assets.
Business:CTO: Chief Technology Officer: An executive responsible for an organization's technological development and new technology.
Business:CYOD: Choose Your Own Device: A mobile device deployment model where employees can choose from a selection of company-approved devices.
Business:DBA: Database Administrator: A person responsible for the design
column4: and repair of an organization's database.

column1: Business:DPO: Data Privacy Officer: An individual responsible for overseeing an organization's data protection strategy and its implementation to ensure compliance with data protection requirements.
Business:DRP: Disaster Recovery Plan: A documented process or set of procedures to recover and protect a business IT infrastructure in the event of a disaster.
Business:ERP: Enterprise Resource Planning: A system that integrates all facets of an operation
Business:EULA: End User License Agreement: A legal contract between a software developer or vendor and the user of the software.
Business:GDPR: General Data Protection Regulation: A regulation in EU law on data protection and privacy for all individuals within the European Union and the European Economic Area.
Business:HA: High Availability: A characteristic of a system
column2: which aims to ensure an agreed level of operational performance
column4: for a higher than normal period.

column1: Business:IRP: Incident Response Plan: A documented plan that outlines the steps an organization will take to respond to a security incident.
Business:ISP: Internet Service Provider: An organization that provides services for accessing

Business:MaaS: Monitoring as a Service: A cloud service model where monitoring capabilities are provided as a service over the internet.
Business:MDM: Mobile Device Management: Software that allows organizations to securely manage and monitor mobile devices
Business:MOA: Memorandum of Agreement: A written document describing a cooperative relationship between two or more parties.
Business:MOU: Memorandum of Understanding: A formal agreement between two or more parties.
Business:MSA: Master Service Agreement: A contract that defines the terms and conditions that will govern future agreements or transactions between two parties.
Business:MSP: Managed Service Provider: A company that remotely manages a customer's IT infrastructure and/or end-user systems.
Business:MSSP: Managed Security Service Provider: A company that provides outsourced monitoring and management of security devices and systems.
Business:MTBF: Mean Time Between Failures: The predicted elapsed time between inherent failures of a mechanical or electronic system during normal system operation.
Business:MTTF: Mean Time to Failure: The average time a non-repairable system or component is expected to function before it fails.
Business:MTTR: Mean Time to Recover: The average time it takes to repair a failed system or component.
Business:NDA: Non-disclosure Agreement: A legal contract between at least two parties that outlines confidential material
column3: or information that the parties wish to share with one another for certain purposes
column4: but wish to restrict access to or by third parties.

column1: Business:PaaS: Platform as a Service: A cloud computing model that provides a platform and environment to allow developers to build
column3: and manage applications without the complexity of building and maintaining the infrastructure typically associated with developing and launching an app.

column1: Business:ROI: Return on Investment: A performance measure used to evaluate the efficiency or profitability of an investment or compare the efficiency of a number of different investments.
Business:RPO: Recovery Point Objective: The maximum tolerable period in which data might be lost from an IT service due to a major incident.
Business:RTO: Recovery Time Objective: The maximum tolerable duration of time that a computer system
column3: or network can be down after a disaster or disruption occurs.

column1: Business:SaaS: Software as a Service: A software distribution model in which a third-party provider hosts applications and makes them available to customers over the Internet.
Business:SLA: Service-level Agreement: A contract between a service provider and a customer that specifies the level of service expected from the provider.
Business:SLE: Single Loss Expectancy: The monetary loss expected each time a risk materializes.
Business:SOW: Statement of Work: A document that describes the work to be performed

Business:WO: Work Order: A document that authorizes and specifies the work to be performed.

Cloud:CSP: Cloud Service Provider: A third-party company that offers cloud-based computing services.

Cloud:VPC: Virtual Private Cloud: A private
column2: isolated section of the Amazon Web Services (AWS) cloud where you can launch AWS resources in a virtual network that you define.

column1: Cryptography:3DES: Triple Data Encryption Standard: A symmetric-key block cipher that applies the DES algorithm three times to each data block.
Cryptography:AES: Advanced Encryption Standard: A symmetric-key block cipher standard adopted by the U.S. government for encrypting electronic data.
Cryptography:AES-256: Advanced Encryption Standards 256-bit: A version of the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) that uses a 256-bit key length for encryption.
Cryptography:CBC: Cipher Block Chaining: A mode of operation for block ciphers
column2: which makes each ciphertext block dependent on all preceding plaintext blocks.

column1: Cryptography:CFB: Cipher Feedback: A mode of operation for block ciphers that makes the block cipher into a self-synchronizing stream cipher.
Cryptography:CTM: Counter Mode: A mode of operation for block ciphers that turns a block cipher into a stream cipher.
Cryptography:DES: Digital Encryption Standard: An outdated symmetric-key algorithm for the encryption of electronic data.
Cryptography:DHE: Diffie-Hellman Ephemeral: A type of Diffie-Hellman key exchange that generates a new key for each session
Cryptography:ECB: Electronic Code Book: A simple and insecure mode of operation for block ciphers
column2: where each block of plaintext is encrypted independently.

column1: Cryptography:ECC: Elliptic Curve Cryptography: An approach to public-key cryptography based on the algebraic structure of elliptic curves over finite fields.
Cryptography:ECDHE: Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman Ephemeral: A key agreement protocol that allows two parties
column2: each having an elliptic curve public-private key pair
column3: to establish a shared secret over an insecure channel.

column1: Cryptography:ECDSA: Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm: A variant of the Digital Signature Algorithm (DSA) which uses elliptic curve cryptography.
Cryptography:GCM: Galois Counter Mode: A mode of operation for block ciphers that provides authenticated encryption.
Cryptography:GPG: Gnu Privacy Guard: A free software implementation of the OpenPGP standard
column2: used for encryption and digital signatures.

column1: Cryptography:HMAC: Hashed Message Authentication Code: A specific type of message authentication code (MAC) involving a cryptographic hash function and a secret cryptographic key.
Cryptography:IDEA: International Data Encryption Algorithm: A symmetric-key block cipher designed as a replacement for DES.
Cryptography:KEK: Key Encryption Key: A cryptographic key that is used to encrypt other keys.
Cryptography:MD5: Message Digest 5: A widely used cryptographic hash function producing a 128-bit hash value.
Cryptography:P12: PKCS #12: A common file format for storing many cryptographic objects as a single file.

Cryptography:PBKDF2: Password-based Key Derivation Function 2: A cryptographic algorithm used to transform a password into a secure cryptographic key to reduce the susceptibility of a system to brute-force attacks; makes it computationally expensive to guess passwords.
Cryptography:PGP: Pretty Good Privacy: An encryption program that provides cryptographic privacy and authentication for data communication.
Cryptography:PKCS: Public Key Cryptography Standards: A group of standards designed to ensure the compatibility and interoperability of public-key cryptography.
Cryptography:PKI: Public Key Infrastructure: A set of roles
Cryptography:PSK: Pre-shared Key: A secret key that has been shared between two parties before it is used to encrypt messages.
Cryptography:RA: Recovery Agent: An agent that can recover encrypted data on behalf of a user.
Cryptography:RC4: Rivest Cipher version 4: A stream cipher widely used in various protocols such as SSL
Cryptography:RIPEMD: RACE Integrity Primitives Evaluation Message Digest: A family of cryptographic hash functions.
Cryptography:RSA: Rivest
column3: & Adleman: A widely used public-key cryptosystem for secure data transmission.

column1: Cryptography:S/MIME: Secure/Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions: A standard for public key encryption and signing of MIME data.
Cryptography:SHA: Secure Hashing Algorithm: A family of cryptographic hash functions.
Cryptography:SSL: Secure Sockets Layer: An outdated cryptographic protocol that provides secure communication over a computer network.
Cryptography:TKIP: Temporal Key Integrity Protocol: An encryption protocol used in the WPA standard for wireless networks.
Cryptography:TLS: Transport Layer Security: A cryptographic protocol designed to provide communications security over a computer network.
Cryptography:TOTP: Time-based One-time Password: An algorithm that computes a one-time password based on the current time and a shared secret key.
Cryptography:TPM: Trusted Platform Module: An international standard for a secure cryptoprocessor
column2: a dedicated microcontroller designed to secure hardware by integrating cryptographic keys into devices.

column1: Cryptography:WEP: Wired Equivalent Privacy: An outdated security algorithm for IEEE 802.11 wireless networks.
Cryptography:DSA: Digital Signature Algorithm: A cryptographic method used to ensure the authenticity
column3: and non-repudiation of digital messages; a public-key cryptosystem standardized by the U.S. Government.

column1: Cryptography:FDE: Full Disk Encryption: The encryption of all data on a hard drive.
CTI:AIS: Automated Indicator Sharing: A program that enables the exchange of cyber threat indicators and defensive measures in real-time.
CTI:APT: Advanced Persistent Threat: A stealthy threat actor
column2: typically a nation-state or state-sponsored group
column3: which gains unauthorized access to a computer network and remains undetected for an extended period.

column1: CTI:ASLR: Address Space Layout Randomization: A security feature that randomly arranges the address space positions of key data areas
column2: including the base of the executable and the positions of the stack

column1: CTI:ATT&CK: Adversarial Tactics
column3: and Common Knowledge: A knowledge base of cyberattack methodologies and is used as a foundation for the development of specific threat models and methodologies.

column1: CTI:AV: Antivirus: Software designed to detect
CTI:CA: Certificate Authority: An entity that issues digital certificates.
CTI:CRL: Certificate Revocation List: A list of digital certificates that have been revoked by the issuing certificate authority before their scheduled expiration date.
CTI:CSR: Certificate Signing Request: A message sent from an applicant to a certificate authority to apply for a digital certificate.
CTI:CVE: Common Vulnerability Enumeration: A dictionary of publicly known information security vulnerabilities and exposures.
CTI:CVSS: Common Vulnerability Scoring System: A free and open industry standard for assessing the severity of computer system security vulnerabilities.
CTI:DDoS: Distributed Denial of Service: A cyberattack where multiple compromised computer systems attack a target
column4: and cause a denial of service for users of the targeted resource.

column1: CTI:DEP: Data Execution Prevention: A security feature that prevents code from being executed in certain memory regions
column2: which helps prevent buffer overflow attacks.

column1: CTI:DLP: Data Loss Prevention: A set of tools and processes used to ensure that sensitive data is not lost

CTI:DoS: Denial of Service: A cyberattack in which the perpetrator seeks to make a machine or network resource unavailable to its intended users by temporarily or indefinitely disrupting services of a host connected to the Internet.
CTI:EDR: Endpoint Detection and Response: An integrated
column2: layered approach to endpoint protection that combines real-time continuous monitoring and collection of endpoint data with automated response capabilities.

column1: CTI:HIDS: Host-based Intrusion Detection System: An intrusion detection system that monitors and analyzes the internals of a computing system as well as the network packets on its network interfaces.

CTI:HIPS: Host-based Intrusion Prevention System: An intrusion prevention system that monitors and analyzes the internals of a computing system as well as the network packets on its network interfaces
column2: and also actively prevents malicious activity.

column1: CTI:IDS: Intrusion Detection System: A system that monitors network traffic for suspicious activity and alerts when such activity is discovered.
CTI:IoC: Indicators of Compromise: Forensic data
column2: such as data found in system or network logs
column3: that identify potentially malicious activity on a system or network.

column1: CTI:IPS: Intrusion Prevention System: A system that monitors network traffic for suspicious activity and takes action to prevent it.
CTI:IR: Incident Response: An organized approach to addressing and managing the aftermath of a security breach or cyberattack.
CTI:IV: Initialization Vector: A fixed-size input to a cryptographic primitive that is typically required to be random or pseudorandom.
CTI:KDC: Key Distribution Center: A network service that provides secret keys to users and applications.
CTI:NIDS: Network-based Intrusion Detection System: An intrusion detection system that monitors network traffic for suspicious activity.
CTI:NIPS: Network-based Intrusion Prevention System: An intrusion prevention system that monitors network traffic for suspicious activity and actively prevents it.
CTI:NIST: National Institute of Standards & Technology: A physical sciences laboratory and non-regulatory agency of the United States Department of Commerce.
CTI:OSINT: Open-source Intelligence: Intelligence collected from publicly available sources.
CTI:OVAL: Open Vulnerability Assessment Language: An international information security standard to promote open and publicly available security content
column2: and standardize the transfer of this information across the entire spectrum of security tools and services.

column1: CTI:PCI DSS: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard: A set of security standards designed to ensure that all companies that accept
column4: or transmit credit card information maintain a secure environment.

column1: CTI:PHI: Personal Health Information: Any information about health status
column3: or payment for health care that can be linked to an individual.

column1: CTI:PII: Personally Identifiable Information: Information that can be used to identify
column4: or to identify an individual in context.

column1: CTI:PIV: Personal Identity Verification: A U.S. government standard for smart cards that contain the necessary data for the cardholder to be identified and verified.
CTI:RA: Registration Authority: An entity in a PKI that verifies the identity of certificate applicants and forwards their requests to a CA.
CTI:RAT: Remote Access Trojan: A type of malware that allows an attacker to control a system remotely.
CTI:RTBH: Remotely Triggered Black Hole: A technique used by ISPs to mitigate denial of service attacks by dropping traffic to a specific destination.
CTI:SE Linux: Security-enhanced Linux: A security module for the Linux kernel that provides a mechanism for supporting access control security policies.
CTI:SIEM: Security Information and Event Management: A solution that provides real-time analysis of security alerts generated by applications and network hardware.
CTI:SOAR: Security Orchestration
column3: Response: A set of software capabilities and services that allow organizations to collect security threats data and alerts from different sources.

column1: CTI:SOC: Security Operations Center: A centralized function within an organization that uses technology
column3: and people to continuously monitor and improve an organization's security posture.

column1: CTI:STIX: Structured Threat Information eXchange: A structured language for sharing cyber threat intelligence.
CTI:SWG: Secure Web Gateway: A network security solution that protects users from web-based threats and enforces internet use policies.
CTI:TAXII: Trusted Automated eXchange of Indicator Information: A standard for automated exchange of cyber threat information.
CTI:TTP: Tactics
column3: and Procedures: A framework used in cybersecurity to describe the behavior of threat actors.

column1: CTI:UBA: User Behavior Analytics: A cybersecurity process that uses analytics to detect insider threats
CTI:UTM: Unified Threat Management: An all-in-one security appliance that provides multiple security functions.
CTI:WIDS: Wireless Intrusion Detection System: A system that monitors wireless network traffic for suspicious activity.
CTI:WIPS: Wireless Intrusion Prevention System: A system that monitors wireless network traffic for suspicious activity and actively prevents it.
CTI:XDR: Extended Detection and Response: A unified security platform that collects and correlates data across multiple security layers to improve threat detection and response.
Devices:NGFW: Next-generation Firewall: A part of the third generation of firewall technology

column3: such as an application firewall and an intrusion prevention system.

column1: Devices:AP: Access Point: A device that creates a wireless local area network (WLAN)

column5: and projects a Wi-Fi signal to a designated area.

column1: Devices:HDD: Hard Disk Drive: A data storage device used for storing and retrieving digital information using rapidly rotating disks coated with magnetic material.
Devices:HSM: Hardware Security Module: A physical computing device that safeguards and manages digital keys for strong authentication and provides cryptoprocessing.
Devices:ICS: Industrial Control Systems: General term for control systems
Devices:IDF: Intermediate Distribution Frame: A cable rack or enclosure that interconnects and manages the telecommunications wiring between a main distribution frame (MDF) and end-user devices.

column1: Devices:LAN: Local Area Network: A computer network that interconnects computers within a limited area such as a residence

Devices:MDF: Main Distribution Frame: A signal distribution frame or cable rack used for interconnecting and managing telecommunication and data cabling between itself and any number of IDFs.
Devices:MFD: Multifunction Device: A device that performs multiple functions

Devices:PED: Personal Electronic Device: Any electronic device that is personally owned and used
Devices:PTZ: Pan-tilt-zoom: A type of camera that can pan

column1: Devices:RAS: Remote Access Server: A server that enables users to connect to a private network remotely.

column1: Devices:SED: Self-encrypting Drives: Hard disk drives or solid-state drives that encrypt data at rest.

Devices:SoC: System on Chip: An integrated circuit that integrates all components of a computer or other electronic system into a single chip.

column3: and blocks HTTP traffic to and from a web application.

column1: Devices:WAP: Wireless Access Point: A device that allows wireless devices to connect to a wired network using Wi-Fi

column1: Devices:RAID: Redundant Array of Inexpensive Disks: A data storage virtualization technology that combines multiple physical disk drive components into one or more logical units for the purposes of data redundancy
General:AI: Artificial Intelligence: The simulation of human intelligence processes by machines

column1: General:BIOS: Basic Input/Output System: Firmware used to perform hardware initialization during the booting process and to provide runtime services for operating systems and programs.

column1: General:CIA: Confidentiality

column1: General:CMS: Content Management System: A software application or set of related programs that are used to create and manage digital content.

column1: General:ESN: Electronic Serial Number: A unique identification number assigned to mobile phones.
General:GPO: Group Policy Object: A collection of settings that define what a system will look like and how it will behave for a defined group of users.
General:GPS: Global Positioning System: A satellite-based navigation system that provides location and time information.

column1: General:IEEE: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers: A professional association for electronic engineering and electrical engineering.

General:MBR: Master Boot Record: A special type of boot sector at the very beginning of partitioned computer mass storage devices.
General:ML: Machine Learning: A subset of artificial intelligence that provides systems the ability to automatically learn and improve from experience without being explicitly programmed.
General:NTFS: New Technology File System: The standard file system of Windows NT and its successors.
General:OS: Operating System: Software that manages computer hardware and software resources and provides common services for computer programs.

General:RACE: Research and Development in Advanced Communications Technologies in Europe: A European Union research program focusing on advanced communications technologies.

General:UAV: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle: An aircraft without a human pilot aboard.
General:UEFI: Unified Extensible Firmware Interface: A specification for a software interface between an operating system and platform firmware.
General:UEM: Unified Endpoint Management: A comprehensive approach to managing all endpoints
General:VM: Virtual Machine: An emulation of a computer system.
General:XOR: Exclusive Or: A logical operation that outputs true only when inputs differ.
Protocol:IM: Instant Messaging: A type of online chat that offers real-time text transmission over the Internet.
Protocol:IRC: Internet Relay Chat: A text-based chat system that allows users to communicate in real-time.
Protocol:OTA: Over the Air: The wireless transmission of data.
Protocol:SSH: Secure Shell: A cryptographic network protocol for operating network services securely over an unsecured network.

Protocol:AH: Authentication Header: A protocol in the IPsec suite that provides connectionless integrity and data origin authentication for IP datagrams and provides protection against replay attacks.
Protocol:ARP: Address Resolution Protocol: A protocol used to resolve IP addresses to MAC addresses.
Protocol:BGP: Border Gateway Protocol: A routing protocol that enables routing decisions on the internet.
Protocol:BPDU: Bridge Protocol Data Unit: A data message exchanged between switches to detect loops and build spanning tree topology.
Protocol:CCMP: Counter Mode/CBC-MAC Protocol: An encryption protocol designed for wireless local area networks (WLANs) that uses AES for encryption.
Protocol:CHAP: Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol: An authentication protocol that periodically verifies the identity of the client by using a three-way handshake.
Protocol:DHCP: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol: A network protocol used to automatically assign IP addresses and other communication parameters to devices connected to a network.
Protocol:DNAT: Destination Network Address Translation: A type of NAT that changes the destination IP address of incoming packets to a different IP address.
Protocol:DNS: Domain Name System: A hierarchical and decentralized naming system for computers
column3: or other resources connected to the Internet or a private network. It translates human-readable domain names into numerical IP addresses.

column1: Protocol:DNSSEC: Domain Name System Security Extensions: A suite of IETF specifications for securing certain kinds of information provided by the Domain Name System.
Protocol:DSL: Digital Subscriber Line: A family of technologies that are used to transmit digital data over telephone lines.
Protocol:ESP: Encapsulated Security Payload: A protocol within the IPsec suite that provides confidentiality
Protocol:FTP: File Transfer Protocol: A standard network protocol used for the transfer of computer files between a client and server on a computer network.
Protocol:FTPS: Secured File Transfer Protocol: An extension of FTP that adds support for the Transport Layer Security (TLS) and Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) cryptographic protocols.

Protocol:GRE: Generic Routing Encapsulation: A tunneling protocol developed by Cisco that can encapsulate a wide variety of network layer protocols inside virtual point-to-point links over an Internet Protocol internetwork.
Protocol:HTTP: Hypertext Transfer Protocol: The underlying protocol used by the World Wide Web.
Protocol:HTTPS: Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure: An extension of HTTP for secure communication over a computer network
Protocol:ICMP: Internet Control Message Protocol: A supporting protocol in the Internet protocol suite
column2: used by network devices to send error messages and operational information.

column1: Protocol:IKE: Internet Key Exchange: The protocol used to set up a security association in the IPsec protocol suite.
Protocol:IMAP: Internet Message Access Protocol: An application layer Internet protocol used by email clients to retrieve email messages from a mail server over a TCP/IP connection.
Protocol:IP: Internet Protocol: The principal communications protocol in the Internet protocol suite for relaying datagrams across network boundaries.
Protocol:IPSec: Internet Protocol Security: A suite of protocols for securing Internet Protocol (IP) communications by authenticating and encrypting each IP packet of a communication session.
Protocol:L2TP: Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol: A tunneling protocol used to support virtual private networks (VPNs) or as part of the delivery of services by ISPs.
Protocol:LDAP: Lightweight Directory Access Protocol: An open
column3: industry standard application protocol for accessing and maintaining distributed directory information services.

column1: Protocol:LEAP: Lightweight Extensible Authentication Protocol: A proprietary version of EAP developed by Cisco.
Protocol:MAC: Media Access Control: A unique identifier assigned to network interfaces for communications within a network segment.
Protocol:MMS: Multimedia Message Service: A standard for sending messages that include multimedia content to and from mobile phones over a cellular network.

Protocol:MPLS: Multi-protocol Label Switching: A routing technique in telecommunications networks that directs data from one network node to the next based on short path labels rather than long network addresses.
Protocol:MSCHAP: Microsoft Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol: A Microsoft version of CHAP.
Protocol:MTU: Maximum Transmission Unit: The largest size packet or frame that can be sent in a network.
Protocol:NAC: Network Access Control: A computer networking solution that uses a set of protocols to define and implement a policy that describes how to secure network access for devices.

Protocol:NAT: Network Address Translation: A method of remapping one IP address space into another by modifying network address information in the IP header of packets while they are in transit across a traffic routing device.
Protocol:NFC: Near Field Communication: A set of communication protocols that enables two electronic devices
column2: one of which is usually a portable device such as a smartphone
column3: to establish communication by bringing them within 4 cm (1.6 in) of each other.

column1: Protocol:NTLM: New Technology LAN Manager: A suite of Microsoft security protocols that provide authentication
Protocol:NTP: Network Time Protocol: A networking protocol for clock synchronization between computer systems over packet-switched
Protocol:OCSP: Online Certificate Status Protocol: An Internet protocol used for obtaining the revocation status of an X.509 digital certificate.
Protocol:OSPF: Open Shortest Path First: A routing protocol for Internet Protocol (IP) networks.
Protocol:P2P: Peer to Peer: A distributed application architecture that partitions tasks or workloads between peers.
Protocol:PAC: Proxy Auto Configuration: A method that allows web browsers and other user agents to automatically choose the correct proxy server for a given URL.
Protocol:PAP: Password Authentication Protocol: A simple authentication protocol that transmits passwords in clear text.
Protocol:PAT: Port Address Translation: A type of network address translation (NAT) that maps multiple internal private IP addresses to a single external public IP address
Protocol:PCAP: Packet Capture: The process of intercepting and logging traffic passing over a digital network or part of a network.
Protocol:PEAP: Protected Extensible Authentication Protocol: A protocol that encapsulates EAP within a TLS tunnel
Protocol:PEM: Privacy Enhanced Mail: An IETF standard for securing email.
Protocol:PFS: Perfect Forward Secrecy: A cryptographic feature ensures session keys are generated uniquely for each session
column2: protecting past communications even if long-term keys are compromised. Common in TLS 1.3

column1: Protocol:POP: Post Office Protocol: An application-layer protocol used by local email clients to retrieve email from a remote server over a TCP/IP connection.
Protocol:POTS: Plain Old Telephone Service: The analog telephone service.
Protocol:PPP: Point-to-Point Protocol: A data link layer (Layer 2) communication protocol used to establish a direct connection between two nodes.
Protocol:PPTP: Point-to-Point Tunneling Protocol: An outdated method for implementing virtual private networks (VPNs).
Protocol:RDP: Remote Desktop Protocol: A proprietary protocol developed by Microsoft
column2: which provides a user with a graphical interface to connect to another computer over a network connection.

column1: Protocol:RTP: Real-time Transport Protocol: A network protocol for delivering audio and video over IP networks.
Protocol:SAML: Security Assertions Markup Language: An open standard for exchanging authentication and authorization data between an identity provider and a service provider.
Protocol:SCAP: Security Content Automation Protocol: A suite of specifications that standardize the way security software products communicate and analyze security data.
Protocol:SCEP: Simple Certificate Enrollment Protocol: A protocol used for enrolling certificates to devices.
Protocol:SFTP: Secured File Transfer Protocol: A network protocol that provides file access
column3: and file management over any reliable data stream.

column1: Protocol:SHTTP: Secure Hypertext Transfer Protocol: An extension to HTTP that provides secure transmission of web pages.

Protocol:SMB: Server Message Block: A network file sharing protocol that allows applications on a computer to read and write to files and to request services from server programs in a computer network.
Protocol:SMS: Short Message Service: A text messaging service component of most telephone
Protocol:SMTP: Simple Mail Transfer Protocol: An Internet standard for electronic mail (email) transmission.
Protocol:SMTPS: Simple Mail Transfer Protocol Secure: An extension of SMTP that adds support for the Transport Layer Security (TLS) and Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) cryptographic protocols.

Protocol:SNMP: Simple Network Management Protocol: An Internet Standard protocol for collecting and organizing information about managed devices on IP networks and for modifying that information to change device behavior.
Protocol:SOAP: Simple Object Access Protocol: A messaging protocol specification for exchanging structured information in the implementation of web services.
Protocol:SRTP: Secure Real-Time Protocol: A profile for RTP that provides confidentiality
column3: and replay protection for RTP traffic.

column1: Protocol:TACACS+: Terminal Access Controller Access Control System: A proprietary protocol developed by Cisco that provides centralized authentication
Protocol:TCP/IP: Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol: The suite of communication protocols used to interconnect network devices on the internet.
Protocol:TSIG: Transaction Signature: A mechanism used to authenticate DNS messages using shared secret keys.
Protocol:UDP: User Datagram Protocol: A communication protocol that offers a limited number of services when messages are exchanged between computers in a network.
Protocol:URI: Uniform Resource Identifier: A string of characters used to identify a resource.
Protocol:URL: Universal Resource Locator: A specific type of URI that specifies the location of a resource on a computer network and a mechanism for retrieving it.
Protocol:USB: Universal Serial Bus: An industry standard that establishes specifications for cables and connectors and protocols for connection
Protocol:USB OTG: USB On The Go: An extension to the USB standard that allows USB devices to act as a host
column2: enabling them to communicate directly with other USB devices.

column1: Protocol:UTP: Unshielded Twisted Pair: A type of copper cable used in local area networks (LANs).
Protocol:VLAN: Virtual Local Area Network: A logical subdivision of a physical network.
Protocol:VLSM: Variable Length Subnet Masking: A technique that allows network administrators to divide an IP address space into subnets of different sizes.
Protocol:VoIP: Voice over IP: A methodology and group of technologies for the delivery of voice communications and multimedia sessions over Internet Protocol (IP) networks.
Protocol:VPN: Virtual Private Network: A technology that creates a secure and encrypted connection over a less secure network
Protocol:VTC: Video Teleconferencing: A technology that allows users in different locations to hold face-to-face meetings virtually.
Protocol:WPA: Wi-Fi Protected Access: A security protocol for wireless networks.
Protocol:WPS: Wi-Fi Protected Setup: A network security standard that allows users to easily secure a wireless home network.
Protocol:WTLS: Wireless TLS: A security layer used in Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) to provide authentication
